citations.narrative:
The front of the shelter area within the large outdoor enclosure housing an adult male camel has fence panels with
spaces large enough to allow the general public to interact directly with him. The male camel was observed to contact the
fence where members of the public were able to get right up to the enclosure fence. The raccoon enclosure also has
fencing with holes large enough for the public to put their fingers or hands in and potentially contact the raccoons if they
approach the fence line. Similarly, the fisher and opossum have mesh fencing large enough for a child’s finger to protrude
through.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so that there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public,
with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of
animals and the public. Allowing people to touch and interact directly with the camel and other animals without proper
distance or barriers plus the supervision of a responsible attendant, does not ensure the safety of the animal or the
general public. Correct by ensuring that there is sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animals and public during
exhibition to protect both the animals and the public.
***Correct by 6/20/25.

There were designated feeding areas in which we observed members of the public able to directly contact animals during
the inspection. There was not a readily identifiable attendant present at all times during the animal contact and feeding
experiences involving: Emu (on the back side of the pen), Elk, Niglai, Fallow Deer, Whitetail and Red deer, the petting zoo
area (Goats, Turkey, Alpacas, Sheep), Mouflon, and Domestic cow.
Other areas in the park encourage feeding with "Feed Me" signs which could allow public contact if animals approach
these areas where an attendant was not present: Aoudad, Water Buffalo, Fallow deer bucks, Sika Deer, Urial Sheep.
Lack of a responsible, knowledgeable, readily identifiable employee or attendant during times of public contact does not
help prevent improper feeding or improper handling of animals and increases risk to the public. If public contact with
certain animals is to be allowed, the licensee must ensure that a responsible, knowledgeable, readily identifiable
employee or attendant is present at all times to protect the public and the animals.
***Correct from 6/13/2025 going forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The front of the shelter area within the large outdoor enclosure housing an adult male camel has fence panels with 
spaces large enough to allow the general public to interact directly with him. The male camel was observed to contact the 
fence where members of the public were able to get right up to the enclosure fence. The raccoon enclosure also has 
fencing with holes large enough for the public to put their fingers or hands in and potentially contact the raccoons if they 
approach the fence line. Similarly, the fisher and opossum have mesh fencing large enough for a child’s finger to protrude 
through.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so that there is minimal risk of harm to the animals and to the public, 
with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of 
animals and the public. Allowing people to touch and interact directly with the camel and other animals without proper 
distance or barriers plus the supervision of a responsible attendant, does not ensure the safety of the animal or the 
general public. Correct by ensuring that there is sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animals and public during 
exhibition to protect both the animals and the public. 
***Correct by 6/20/25. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
There were designated feeding areas in which we observed members of the public able to directly contact animals during 
the inspection. There was not a readily identifiable attendant present at all times during the animal contact and feeding 
experiences involving: Emu (on the back side of the pen), Elk, Niglai, Fallow Deer, Whitetail and Red deer, the petting zoo 
area (Goats, Turkey, Alpacas, Sheep), Mouflon, and Domestic cow.  
 
Other areas in the park encourage feeding with "Feed Me" signs which could allow public contact if animals approach 
these areas where an attendant was not present: Aoudad, Water Buffalo, Fallow deer bucks, Sika Deer, Urial Sheep. 
Lack of a responsible, knowledgeable, readily identifiable employee or attendant during times of public contact does not 
help prevent improper feeding or improper handling of animals and increases risk to the public. If public contact with 
certain animals is to be allowed, the licensee must ensure that a responsible, knowledgeable, readily identifiable

employee or attendant is present at all times to protect the public and the animals. 
***Correct from 6/13/2025 going forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
